column33: Name Origin
column34: Description
column38: Sources.
column39: Uses

column33: Greek: hydro (water) and genes (generate)
column34: Tasteless, colorless, odorless gas. The most abundant element in the universe. Tenth most abundant element in the earth's crust.
column38: Commercial quantities are produced by reacting superheated steam with methane or carbon. In lab work from reaction of metals with acid solutions or electrolysis.
column39: Most hydrogen is used in the production of ammonia. Also used in balloons and in metal refining. Also used as fuel in rockets. Its two heavier isotopes are: deuterium (D) and tritium (T) used respectively for nuclear fission and fusion.

column33: Greek: hêlios (sun).
column34: Light, odorless, colorless, tasteless inert gas. Second most abundant element in the universe. Sixth most abundant in the earth's atmosphere.
column35: Sir William Ramsey, Nils Langet, P.T.Cleve
column38: Found in natural gas deposits & in the air (5 parts per billion) Constantly lost to space; replenished by radioactive decay (alpha particles).
column39: Used in balloons, deep sea diving & welding. Also used in very low temperature research.

column33: Greek: lithos (stone).
column34: Soft silvery-white metal. Lightest of metals. Accounts for only 0.0007% of the earth's crust.
column38: Obtained by passing electric charge through melted lithium chloride and from the silicate mineral called spodumene [LiAl(Si2O6)].
column39: Used in batteries. Also for certain kinds of glass and ceramics.  Some is used in lubricants.

column33: Greek: beryllos, "beryl" (a mineral).
column34: Hard, brittle, steel-gray metal. Lightest rigid metal. Formerly called glucinium (Gl) for its sweet but deadly taste.
column38: Found mostly in minerals like beryl [AlBe3(Si6O18)] and chrysoberyl (Al2BeO4). Pure beryllium is obtained by chemically reducing beryl mineral. Also by electrolysis of beryllium chloride.
column39: Its ability to absorb large amounts of heat makes it useful in spacecraft, missiles, aircraft, etc. Emeralds are beryl crystals with chromium traces giving them their green color.

column33: From Arabic and Persian words for borax.
column34: Hard, brittle, lustrous black semimetal. Exists in the earth's crust at an average proportion of about 10 parts per million.
column35: Sir H. Davy, J.L. Gay-Lussac, L.J. Thénard
column38: Obtained from kernite, a kind of borax (Na2B4O7.10H2O). High purity boron is produced by electrolysis of molten potassium fluroborate and potassium chloride (KCl).
column39: Used with titanium & tungsten to make heat resistant alloys for jets & rockets.

column33: Latin: carbo, (charcoal).
column34: Allotropic forms include diamonds and graphite. Sixth most abundant element in the universe.
column38: Made by burning organic compounds with insufficient oxygen.
column39: For making steel, in filters, and many more uses. Radiocarbon dating uses the carbon-14 isotope to date old objects.

column33: Greek: nitron and genes, (soda forming).
column34: Colorless, odorless, tasteless, generally inert gas. Fifth most abundant element in the universe. Makes up about 78% of earth's atmosphere.
column38: Obtained from liquid air by fractional distillation.
column39: Primarily to produce ammonia and other fertilizers. Also used in making nitric acid, which is used in explosives. Also used in welding and enhanced oil recovery.

column33: Greek: oxys and genes, (acid former).
column34: Colorless, odorless, tasteless gas; pale blue liquid. Third most abundant element in the universe. It is the most abundant element in the earth's crust, and makes up almost 21% of the atmosphere.
column38: Obtained primarily from liquid air by fractional distillation. Small amounts are made in the laboratory by electrolysis of water or heating potassium chlorate (KClO3) with manganese dioxide (MnO2) catalyst.
column39: Used in steel making, welding, and supporting life. Naturally occuring ozone (O3) in the upper atmosphere shields the earth from ultraviolet radiation.

column33: Latin: fluere (flow).
column34: Greenish-yellow, pungent, corrosive gas. Extremely reactive. Does not occur uncombined in nature.
column38: Found in the minerals fluorite (CaF2) and cryolite(Na3AlF6). Electrolysis of hydrofluoric acid (HF) or potassium acid fluoride (KHF2) is the only practical method of commercial production.
column39: Used in refrigerants and other fluorocarbons. Also in toothpaste as sodium fluoride (NaF) and stannous fluoride (SnF2); also in Teflon.

column33: Greek: neos (new).
column34: Colorless, odorless, tasteless inert gas. Fourth most abundant element in the universe and fifth most abundant in the earth's atmosphere (18.18 ppm).
column38: Obtained from production of liquid air as a byproduct of producing liquid oxygen and nitrogen.
column39: Primarily for lighting.

column33: Medieval Latin: sodanum, (headache remedy); symbol from Latin natrium, (sodium carbonate).
column34: Soft silvery-white metal. Sixth most abundant element in the earth's crust. Burns in air with a brilliant white flame.
column38: Obtained by electrolysis of melted sodium chloride (salt), borax and cryolite.
column39: There are few uses for the pure metal, however its compounds are used in medicine, agriculture and photography. Sodium chloride (NaCl) is table salt. Liquid sodium is sometimes used to cool nuclear reactors.

column33: From Magnesia ancient city in district of Thessaly, Greece.
column34: Lightweight, malleable, silvery-white metal. Eighth most abundant element in the universe. Seventh most abundant element in the earth's crust.
column38: Usually obtained by electrolysis of melted magnesium chloride (MgCl2) found in sea water. Each cubic mile of seawater contains about 12 billion pounds of magnesium.
column39: Used in alloys to make airplanes, missiles and other uses for light metals. Has structural properties similar to aluminium. But since it is flammable at temperatures of burning gasoline, its uses are limited.

column33: Latin: alumen, aluminis, (alum).
column34: Soft, lightweight, silvery-white metal. Third most abundant element in the earth's crust.
column38: Never occurs in free form. Obtained by electrolysis from bauxite (Al2O3).
column39: Used for many purposes from airplanes to beverage cans. Too soft in its pure form so less than 1% of silicon or iron is added, which hardens and strengthens it.

column33: Latin: silex, silicus, (flint).
column34: Amorphous form is brown power; crystalline form has gray metallic appearance. Seventh most abundant element in the universe. Second most plentiful element in the earths crust.
column38: Makes up major portion of clay, granite, quartz (SiO2), and sand. Commercial production depends on a reaction between sand (SiO2) and carbon at a temperature of around 2200 °C.
column39: Used in glass as silicon dioxide (SiO2). Silicon carbide (SiC) is one of the hardest substances known and used in polishing. Also the crystalline form is used in semiconductors.

column33: Greek: phosphoros, (bringer of light).
column34: Soft white waxy phosphorescent solid, brownish-red powder or black solid.
column38: Found most often in phosphate rock. Pure phosphorus is obtained by heating a mixture of phosphate rock, coke, and silica to about 1450 °C.
column39: Used in the production of fertilizers and detergents. Some is used in fireworks, safety matches, and incendiary weapons. Also some applications for it and some of its compounds which glow in the dark.

column33: Latin: sulphur (brimstone).
column34: Tasteless, odorless, pale yellow, brittle solid. Tenth most abundant element in the universe.
column38: Found in pure form and in ores like cinnabar, galena, sphalerite and stibnite. Pure form is obtained from undergound deposits by the Frasch process.
column39: Used in matches, gunpowder, medicines, rubber and pesticides, dyes and insecticides. Also for making sulfuric acid (H2SO4).

column33: Greek: chlôros (greenish yellow).
column34: Greenish-yellow, disagreeable gas. Never found in free form in nature.
column38: Salt (sodium chloride, NaCl) is its most common compound. Commercial quantities are produced by electrolysis of aqueous sodium chloride (seawater or brine from salt mines).
column39: Used in water purification, bleaches, acids and many, many other compounds such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFC).

column33: Greek: argos (inactive).
column34: Colorless, odorless, tasteless noble gas. It is the third most abundant element in the earth's atmosphere and makes up about 1%.
column38: Continuously released into the air by decay of radioactive potassium-40. Pure form is obtained from fractional distillation of liquid air.
column39: Used in lighting products. It is often used in filling incandescent light bulbs. Some is mixed with krypton in fluorescent lamps. Crystals in the semiconductor industry are grown in argon atmospheres.

column33: English: pot ash; symbol from Latin: kalium, (alkali).
column34: Soft, waxy, silver-white metal. Eighth most abundant element in the earth's crust (20,900 ppm). Occurs only in compounds.
column38: Found in minerals like carnallite [(KMgCl3).6H2O] & sylvite (potassium chloride, KCL). Pure metal is produced by the reaction of hot potassium chloride and sodium vapors in a special retort.
column39: Used as potash in making glass & soap. Also as saltpeter, potassium nitrate (KNO3) to make explosives and to color fireworks in mauve. Formerly called kalium (K). Vital to function of nerve and muscle tissures.

column33: Latin: calx, calcis (lime).
column34: Fairly hard, silvery-white metal. Fifth most abundant element in the earth's crust (41,500 ppm). Occurs only in compounds.
column38: Obtained from minerals like chalk, limestone & marble. Pure metal is produced by replacing the calcium in lime (calcium carbonate, CaCO3) with aluminium in hot, low pressure retorts.
column39: Used by many forms of life to make shells and bones. Virtually no use for the pure metal, however two of its compounds are, lime (CaO) and gypsum (CaSO4), are in great demand by a number of industries.

column33: Latin: Scandia, Scandinavia.
column34: Fairly soft, silvery-white metal. Eighth most abundant 'rare earth' found in the earth's crust (5.0 ppm).
column38: Occurs mainly in the minerals thortveitile (~34% scandium) and wiikite. Also in some tin and tungsten ores. Pure scandium is obtained as a by-product of uranium refining.
column39: Scandium metal is used in some aerospace applications. Scandum oxide (Sc2O3) is used in the manufacture of high-intensity electric lamps. Scandium iodide (ScI3) is used in lamps that produce light having a color closely matching natural sunlight.

column33: Greek: titanos (Titans).
column34: Shiny, dark-gray metal. Ninth most abundant element in the earth's crust (5700 ppm). It can be highly polished, and is relatively immune to tarnishing.
column38: Usually occurs in the minerals ilmenite (FeTiO3) or rutile (TiO2). Also in Titaniferous magnetite, titanite (CaTiSiO5), and iron ores. Pure metal produced by heating TiO2 with C and Cl2  to produce TiCl4 then heated with Mg gas in Ar atmosphere.
column39: Since it is strong and resists acids it is used in many alloys. Titanium dioxide (TiO2), a white pigment that covers surfaces very well, is used in paint, rubber, paper and many others.

column33: From Scandinavian goddess, Vanadis.
column34: Soft, ductile, silvery-white metal. Resistant to corrosion by moisture, air and most acids and alkalis at room temperature.
column38: Found in the minerals patronite (VS4), vanadinite [Pb5(VO4)3Cl], and carnotite [K2(UO2)2(VO4)2.3H2O]. Pure metal produced by heating with C and Cl to produce VCl3 which is heated  with Mg in Ar atmosphere.
column39: It is mixed with other metals to make very strong and durable alloys. Vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) is used as a catalyst, dye and color-fixer.

column33: Greek: chrôma (color).
column34: Very hard, crystalline, steel-gray metal. The pure metal has a blue-white color. It is hard, brittle and corrsion-resistant at normal temperatures.
column38: Chromite [Fe,Mg(CrO4)] is its most important mineral. Produced commercially by heating its ore in the presence of silicon or aluminium.
column39: Used to make stainless steel. It gives the color to rubies and emeralds. Iron-nickel-chromium alloys in various percentages yield an incredible variety of the most important metals in modern technology.

column33: Latin: magnes (magnet); Italian: manganese.
column34: Hard, brittle, gray-white metal with a pinkish tinge. Rusts like iron in moist air.
column38: Most abundant ores are pyrolusite (MnO2), psilomelane [(Ba,H2O)2Mn5O10] and rhodochrosite (MnCO3). Pure metal produced by mixing MnO2 with powered Al and ignited in a furnace.
column39: Used in steel, batteries and ceramics. The steel in railroad tracks can contain as much as 1.2% manganese. It is crucial to the effectiveness of vitamin B1.

column33: Anglo-Saxon: iron; symbol from Latin: ferrum (iron).
column34: Malleable, ductile, silvery-white metal. Fourth most abundant element in the earth's crust (56,300 ppm). Ninth most abundant element in the universe.
column38: Obtained from iron ores. Pure metal produced in blast furnaces by layering limestone, coke and iron ore and forcing hot gasses into the bottom.  This heats the coke red hot and the iron is reduced from its oxides and liquified where it flows to the bottom
column39: Used in steel and other alloys. Essential for humans. It is the chief constituent of hemoglobin which carries oxygen in blood vessels. Its oxides are used in magnetic tapes and disks.

column33: German: kobold (goblin).
column34: Hard, ductile, lustrous bluish-gray metal. Exists in the earth's curst in cocentrations of about 25 ppm. It has remarkable magnetic properties.
column38: Occurs in compounds with arsenic, oxygen and sulfur as in cobaltine (CoAsS) and linneite (Co3S4). Pure cobalt is obtained as a byproduct of refining nickel, copper and iron.
column39: Used in many hard alloys; for magnets, ceramics and special glasses. Remains hard up to 982°C. Radioactive cobalt-60 is used in cancer therapy.

column33: German: kupfernickel (false copper).
column34: Hard, malleable, silvery-white metal. Found in the earth's crust in portions averaging 70 ppm. It can be polished to a lustrous finish. Virtually no corrosion under normal conditions.
column38: Chiefly found in pentlandite [(Ni,Fe)9S8] ore. The metal is produced by heating the ore in a blast furnace which replaces the sulfur with oxygen. The oxides are then treated with an acid that reacts with the iron not the nickel.
column39: Used in electroplating and metal alloys because of its resistance to corrosion. Also in nickel-cadmium batteries; as a catalyst and for coins.

column33: Symbol from Latin: cuprum (island of Cyprus famed for its copper mines).
column34: Malleable, ductile, reddish-brown metal.
column38: Pure copper occurs rarely in nature. Usually found in sulfides as in chalcopyrite (CuFeS2), coveline (CuS), chalcosine (Cu2S) or oxides like cuprite (Cu2O).
column39: Most often used as an electrical conductor. Also used in the manufacture of water pipes. Its alloys are used in jewelry and for coins.

column33: German: zink (German for tin).
column34: Bluish-silver, ductile metal.
column38: Found in the minerals zinc blende (sphalerite) (ZnS), calamine, franklinite, smithsonite (ZnCO3), willemite, and zincite (ZnO).
column39: Used to coat other metal (galvanizing) to protect them from rusting. Also used in alloys such as brass, bronze, nickel. Also in solder, cosmetics and pigments.

column33: Latin: Gallia (France).
column34: Soft, blue-white metal.
column38: Found throughout the crust in minerals like bauxite, germanite and coal.
column39: Used in semiconductor production. It us used in making LEDs (light-emitting diodes) and GaAs laser diodes.

column33: Latin: Germania (Germany).
column34: Grayish-white metal.
column38: Obtained from refining copper, zinc and lead.
column39: Widely used in semiconductors. It is a good semiconductor when combined with tiny amounts of phosphorus, arsenic, gallium, and antimony.

column33: Greek: arsenikon; Latin: arsenicum, (both names for yellow pigment).
column34: Steel-gray, brittle semi-metal.
column38: Found in mispickel (arsenopyrite)
column39: Many of its compounds are deadly poison and used as weed killer and rat poison. Conducts electricity. Used in semiconductors. Some compounds, called arsenides, are used in the manufacture of paints, wallpapers, and ceramics.

column33: Greek: selênê (moon).
column34: Soft metalloid similar to sulfur. Ranges from gray metallic to red glassy appearance.
column38: Obtained from lead, copper and nickel refining. Conducts electricity when struck by light.
column39: Light causes it to conduct electricity more easily. It is used in photoelectric cells, TV cameras, xerography machines and as a semiconductor in solar batteries and rectifiers. Also colors glass red.

column33: Greek: brômos (stench).
column34: Redish-brown liquid.
column38: Occurs in compounds in sea water.
column39: It was once used in large quantities to make a compound that removed lead compound build up in engines burning leaded gasoline. Now it is primarily used in dyes, disinfectants, and photographic chemicals.

column33: Greek: kryptos (hidden).
column34: Colorless, odorless, tasteless rare noble gas.
column38: Forms 1 millionth of the atmosphere. Obtained from production of liquid air.
column39: Used in lighting products. Some is used as inert filler-gas in incandescent bulbs. Some is mixed with argon in fluorescent lamps. The most important use is in flashing stroboscopic lamps that outline airport runways.

column33: Latin: rubidus (deep red); the color its salts impart to flames.
column34: Soft, silvery-white, highly reactive metal.
column38: Occurs abundantly, but so widespread that production is limited. Usually obtained from lithium production.
column39: Used as a catalyst, photocells, and vacuum and cathode-ray tubes.

column33: From the Scottish town, Strontian.
column34: Soft, malleable, silvery-yellow metal.
column38: Found in minerals celestite and strontianite.
column39: Used in flares and fireworks for crimson color. Strontium-90 is a long lived highly radioactive fallout product of atomic-bomb explosions.

column33: From the Swedish village, Ytterby, where one of its minerals was first found.
column34: Silvery, ductile, fairly reactive metal.
column38: Found in minerals such as monazite, xenotime, and yttria.
column39: Combined with europium to make red phosphors for color TV's. Yttrium oxide and iron oxide combine to form a crystal garnet used in radar.

column33: From the mineral, zircon.
column34: Gray-white, lustrous, corrosion-resistant metal.
column38: Found in many minerals such as zircon and baddeleyite.
column39: Used in alloys such as zircaloy which is used in nuclear applications since it does not readily absorb neutrons. Also baddeleyite is used in lab crucibles. Used in high-performance pumps and valves. Clear zircon (ZrSiO4) is a popular gemstone.

column33: From Niobe; daughter of the mythical Greek king Tantalus.
column34: Shiny white, soft, ductile metal.
column38: Occurs in a mineral columbite. Formerly known as colombium (Cb). It is used in stainless steel alloys for nuclear reactors, jets and missiles.
column39: Used as an alloy with iron and nickel. It can be used in nuclear reactors and is known to be superconductive when alloyed with tin, aluminum or zirconium.

column33: Greek: molybdos (lead).
column34: Hard, silvery-white metal.
column38: Found in the minerals molybdenite (MoS2) and wulfenite (MoO4Pb).
column39: Its alloys are used in aircraft, missiles, and protective coatings in boiler plate.

column33: Greek: technêtos (artificial).
column34: Silvery-gray metal. First synthetically produced element.
column38: Made first by bombarding molybdenum with deuterons (heavy hydrogen) in a cyclotron.
column39: Added to iron in quantities as low as 55 part-per-million transforms the iron into a corrosion-resistant alloy.

column33: Latin: Ruthenia (Russia).
column34: Rare, extremely brittle, silver-gray metal.
column38: Found in pentlandite and pyroxinite.
column39: Used to harden platinum and palladium. Aircraft magnetos use platinum alloy with 10% ruthenium.

column33: Greek: rhodon (rose). Its salts give a rosy solution.
column34: Hard, silvery-white metal
column38: Obtained as a by-product of nickel production.
column39: Used as a coating to prevent wear on high quality science equipment and with platinum to make thermocouples.

column33: Named after the asteroid, Pallas, discovered in 1803.
column34: Soft, malleable, ductile, silvery-white metal.
column38: Obtained with platinum, nickel, copper and mercury ores.
column39: Used as a substitue for silver in dental items and jewelry. The pure metal is used as the delicate mainsprings in analog wristwatches. Also used in surgical instruments and as catalyst .

column33: Anglo-Saxon: siolful, (silver); symbol from Latin: argentium.
column34: Silvery-ductile, and malleable metal
column38: Found in ores called argentite (AgS), light ruby silver (Ag3AsS3), dark ruby silver(Ag3SbS3) and brittle silver.
column39: Used in alloys for jewelry and in other compounds for photography. It is also a good conductor, but expensive.

column33: Greek: kadmeia (ancient name for calamine (zinc oxide)).
column34: Soft, malleable, blue-white metal.
column38: Obtained as a by product of zinc refining.
column39: Used in nickel-cadmium batteries. Also in electroplating steel and in the manufacture of berings. Its compounds are found in paint pigments and a wide variety of intense colors. Boiling cadmium gives off a weird, yellow-colored vapor that is poisonous.

column33: Latin: indicum (color indigo), the color it shows in a spectroscope.
column34: Rare, very soft, silver-white metal
column38: Found in certain zinc ores.
column39: Used to coat high speed bearings and as an alloy that lowers the melting point of other metals. Relativly small amounts are used in dental items and in electronic semiconductors.

column33: Named after Etruscan god, Tinia; symbol from Latin: stannum (tin).
column34: Silvery-white, soft, malleable and ductile metal.
column38: Principally found in the ore cassiterite(SnO2) and stannine (Cu2FeSnS4).
column39: Used as a coating for steel cans since it is nontoxic and noncorrosive. Also in solder (33%Sn:67%Pb), bronze (20%Sn:80%Cu), and pewter. Stannous fluoride (SnF2), a compound of tin and fluorine is used in some toothpaste.

column33: Greek: anti and monos (not alone); symbol from mineral stibnite.
column34: Hard, brittle, silvery-white semimetal.
column38: Found in stibnite (Sb2S3) and in valentinite (Sb2O3).
column39: It is alloyed with other metals to increase their hardness. Also in the manufacture of a few special types of semiconductor devices. Also in plastics and chemicals. A few kinds of over-the-counter cold and flu remedies use antimony compounds.

column33: Latin: tellus (earth).
column34: Silvery-white, brittle simi-metal.
column38: Obtained as a by-product of copper and lead refining.
column39: Used to improve the machining quality of copper and stainless steel products and to color glass and ceramics. Also in thermoelectric devices. Some is used in the rubber industry and it is a basic ingredient in manufacturing blasting caps.

column33: Greek: iôeides (violet colored).
column34: Shiny, black, non-metalic solid; as a gas it is violet and intensely irritating to the eyes, nose and throat.
column38: Occurs on land and in the sea in sodium and potassium compounds.
column39: Required in small amounts by humans. Once used as an antiseptic, but no longer due to its poisonous nature.

column33: Greek: xenos (strange).
column34: Heavy, colorless, odorless, noble gas.
column35: Sir William Ramsay; M. W. Travers
column38: Obtain from the small quantities in liquid air.
column39: Used for filling flash lamps and other powerful lamps. Electrical excitation of xenon produces a burst of brilliant whtie light. Also used in bubble chambers and modern nuclear power reactors.

column33: Latin: coesius (sky blue); for the blue lines of its spectrum.
column34: Very soft, light gray, ductile metal.
column38: Found in pollucite [(Cs4Al4Si9O26).H2O] and as trace in lepidolite.
column39: Used as a 'getter' to remove air traces in vacuum and cathode-ray tubes. Also used in producing photoelectric devices and atomic clocks. Since it ionizes readily, it is used as an ion rocket motor propellant.

column33: Greek: barys (heavy or dense).
column34: Soft, slightly malleable, silvery-white metal.
column38: Found in barytine (BaSO4) and witherite (BaCO3), never found in pure form due to its reactivity. Must be stored under kerosene to remain pure.
column39: Barite, or barium sulfate (BaSO4), when ground is used as a filter for rubber, plastics, and resins. It is insoluable in water and so is used in X-rays of the digestive system. Barium nitrate, Ba(NO3)2, burns brilliant green and is used in fireworks.

column33: Greek: lanthanein (to be hidden).
column34: Soft, silvery-white, malleable, ductile metal.
column38: Found with rare earths in monazite and bastnasite. Monazite sand typicall contains 25% lanthanum.
column39: It is used in the electodes of high-intensity, carbon-arc lights. Also used in the production of high-grade europium metal. Because it gives glass refractive properties, it is used in expensive camera lenses.

column33: Named after the asteroid, Ceres, discovered two years before the element.
column34: Malleable, ductile, iron-gray metal.
column35: W. von Hisinger, J. Berzelius, M. Klaproth
column38: Most abundant rare earth metal. Found in many minerals like monazite sand [Ce(PO4)].
column39: Its oxides are used in the optics and glass-making industries. Its salts are used in the photography and textile industry. Used in high-intensity carbon lamps and as alloying agents in special metals.

column33: Greek: prasios and didymos (green twin); from its green salts.
column34: Silvery white, moderately soft, malleable, ductile metal.
column38: Obtained from same salts as neodymium.
column39: Used with neodymium to make lenses for glass maker's goggles since it filters out the yellow light present in glass blowing. Alloyed with magnesium creates a high-strength metal used in aircraft engines. Makes up 5% of Mich metal.

column33: Greek: neos and didymos (new twin).
column34: Silvery-white, rare-earth metal that oxidizes easily in air.
column38: Made from electrolysis of its halide salts, which are made from monazite sand.
column39: Used in making artificial ruby for lasers. Also in ceramics and for a special lens with praseodymium. Also to produce bright purple glass and special glass that filters infrared radiation. Makes up 18% of Mich metal, which is used in making steel.

column33: Named for the Greek god, Prometheus.
column34: Rare earth metal of synthetic origin on the earth, naturally made in stars.
column35: J.A. Marinsky, L.E. Glendenin, C.D. Coryell
column38: Does not occur naturally. Found among fission products of uranium, thorium, and plutonium.
column39: It has been used as a source of radioactivity for thickness-measuring gages.

column33: Named after the mineral samarskite.
column34: Silvery rare earth metal.
column38: Found with other rare earths in monazite sand. The sand is often 50% rare earths by weight and 2.8% samarium.
column39: It is used in the electronics and ceramics industries.  It is easily magnetized and very difficult to demagnetize. This suggests important future applications in solid-state and superconductor technologies.

column33: Named for the continent of Europe.
column34: Soft, silvery-white metal.
column38: Obtained from monazite sand, which is a mixture of phosphates of calcium, thorium, cerium, and most other rare earths.
column39: Used with yttrium oxide to make red phosphors for color televisions.

column33: Named after the mineral gadolinite.
column34: Soft, ductile, silvery-white metal.
column38: Found with other rare earths in gadolinite and monazite sand.
column39: Used in steel alloying agents and the manufacture of electronic components.

column33: Named after Ytterby, a village in Sweden.
column34: Soft, ductile, silvery-gray, rare earth metal.
column38: Found with other rare earths in monazite sand, which typically contain 0.03% terbium. Other sources are xenotime and euxenite, both of which are oxide mixtures that can contain up to 1% terbium.
column39: It is used in modest amounts in special lasers and solid-state devices.

column33: Greek: dysprositos (hard to get at).
column34: Soft, lustrous, silvery metal.
column38: Usually found with erbium, holmium and other rare earths in some minerals such as monazite sand, which is often 50% rare earth by weight.
column39: Its uses are limited to the experimental and esoteric.

column33: From Holmia, the Latinized name for Stockholm, Sweden.
column34: Fairly soft, malleable, lustrous, silvery metal.
column38: Occurs in gadolinite. Most often from monazite which is often 50% rare earth and typically 0.05% holmium.
column39: It has very few practical applications; however, it has some unusual magnetic properties that offer some hope for future applications.

column33: Named after the Swedish town, Ytterby.
column34: Soft, malleable, silvery metal.
column38: Found with other heavier rare earths in xenotime and euxerite.
column39: Erbium oxide is used in ceramics to obtain a pink glaze. Also a few uses in the nuclear industry and as an alloying agent for other exotic metals. For example, it increases the malleability of vanadium.

column33: From Thule ancient name of Scandinavia.
column34: Soft, malleable, ductile, silvery metal
column38: Found with other rare earths in the minerals gadolinite, euxenite, xenotime, and monazite. Monazite is often 50% rare earth by weight and 0.007% thulium.
column39: Radioactive thulium is used to power portable x-ray machines, eliminating the need for electrical equipment.

column33: Named for the Swedish village of Ytterby.
column34: Silvery, lustrous, malleable, and ductile metal.
column38: Found in minerals such as yttria, monazite, gadolinite, and xenotime. Monazite is often 50% rare earth by weight and typically 0.03% ytterbium.
column39: Used in metallurgical and chemical experiments.

column33: Named for the ancient name of Paris, Lutecia.
column34: Silvery-white, hard, dense, rare earth metal.
column38: Found with ytterbium in gadolinite and xenotime. Usually obtained from monazite sand which is ofter 50% rare earth by weight and 0.003% lutetium.
column39: It has no practical applications.

column33: From Hafnia, the Latin name of Copenhagen.
column34: Silvery, ductile metal.
column38: Obtained from mineral zircon or baddeleyite.
column39: Used in reactor control rods because of its ability to absorb neutrons.

column33: From king Tantalus of Greek mythology, father of Niobe.
column34: Rare, gray, heavy, hard but ductile, metal with a high melting point.
column38: Chiefly occurs in the mineral tantalite. Always found with niobium.
column39: Often used as an economical substitute for platinum. Tantalum pentoxide is used in capacitors and in camera lenses to increase refracting power. It and its alloys are corrosion and wear resistant so it is used to make surgical and dental tools.

column33: Swedish: tung sten (heavy stone): symbol from its German name wolfram.
column34: Hard, steel-gray to white metal. Highest melting point of all metals.
column35: Fausto and Juan José de Elhuyar
column38: Occurs in the minerals scheelite (CaWO4) and wolframite [(Fe,Mn)WO4].
column39: Made into filaments for vacuum tubes and electric lights. Also as contact points in cars. Combined with calcium or magnesium it makes phosphors. Tungsten carbide is extremely hard and is used for making cutting tools and abrasives.

column33: Latin: Rhenus, the Rhine River.
column34: Rare and costly, dense, silvery-white metal.
column35: Walter Noddack, Ida Tacke, Otto Berg
column38: Found in small amounts in gadolinite and molybdenite. Has a very high melting point.
column39: Mixed with tungsten or platinum to make filaments for mass spectrographs. Its main value is as a trace alloying agent for hardening metal components that are subjected to continuous frictional forces.

column33: Greek: osmê (odor).
column34: Hard fine black powder or hard, lustrous, blue-white metal.
column38: Obtained from the same ores as platinum.
column39: Used to tip gold pen points, instrument pivots, to make electric light filaments. Used for high temp. alloys and pressure bearings. Very hard and resists corrosion better than any other.

column33: Latin: iris (rainbow).
column34: Heavy, brittle, white metal.
column38: Found in gravel deposits with platinum.
column39: Used with osmium to tip gold pen points, to make crucible and special containers. Also to make alloys used for standard weights and measures, and heat-resistant alloys. Also as hardening agent for platinum.

column33: Spanish: platina (little silver).
column34: Rare, very heavy, soft, silvery-white metal.
column38: Produced from deposits of native, or elemental, platinum.
column39: Used in jewelry, to make crucible and special containers and as a catalyst. Used with cobalt to produce very strong magnets. Also to make standard weights and measures. Resists corrosion and acid attacks except aqua regia.

column33: Anglo-Saxon: geolo (yellow); symbol from Latin: aurum (shining dawn).
column34: Soft, malleable, bright yellow metal.
column38: Found in veins in the crust, with cooper ore and native .
column39: Very malleable. Used in electronics, jewelry and coins. It is a good reflector of infrared radiation, so a thin film of gold is applied to the glass of skyscrapers to reduce internal heating from sunlight.

column33: From the Roman god Mercury; symbol from Latin: hydrargyrus (liquid silver).
column34: Heavy, silver-white metal, liquid at ordinary temperatures.
column38: Virtually all mercury comes from cinnabar or mercury sulfide (HgS). Some sources of red cinnabar are so rich in mercury that droplets of elemental mercury can be found in random samples.
column39: Used in thermometers, barometers, and batteries. Also used in electrical switches and mercury-vapor lighting products.

column33: Greek: thallos (green twig), for a bright green line in its spectrum.
column34: Soft gray metal that looks like lead.
column38: Found in iron pyrites. Also in crookesite, hutchinsonite and lorandite. Most is recovered from the byproducts of lead and zinc refining.
column39: Its compounds are used in rat and ant poisons. Also for detecting infrared radiation.

column33: Anglo-Saxon: lead; symbol from Latin: plumbum.
column34: Very soft, highly malleable and ductile, blue-white shiny metal.
column38: Found most often in ores called galena or lead sulfide (PbS). Some is found in its native state.
column39: Used in solder, shielding against radiation and in batteries.

column33: German: bisemutum, (white mass), Now spelled wismut.
column34: Hard, brittle, steel-gray metal with a pink tint.
column38: It can be found free in nature and in minerals like bismuthine (Bi2O3) and in bismuth ochre (Bi2O3)
column39: Main use is in pharmaceuticals and low melting point alloys used as fuses.

column33: Named for Poland, native country of Marie Curie.
column34: Silvery-gray, extremely rare, radioactive metal.
column38: Occurs in pitchblende from decay of bismuth.
column39: Used in industrial equipment that eliminates static electricity caused by such processes as rolling paper, wire, and sheet metal.

column33: Greek: astatos (unstable).
column34: Unstable, radioactive member of the halogen group.
column38: Does not occur in nature. Similar to iodine. Produced by bombarding bismuth with alpha particles.
column39: Since its isotopes have such short half-lives there are no commercially significant compounds of astatine.

column33: Variation of the name of another element, radium.
column34: Colorless, odorless, tasteless, radioactive, heavy, noble gas.
column38: Formed from the decay of radium in the earths crust.
column39: Used to treat some forms of cancer.

column33: Named for France, the nation of its discovery.
column34: Highly rare and unstable, radioactive metal.
column38: Formed by decay of actinium. Chemical properties similar to cesium. Decays to radium or astatine.
column39: Since its isotopes have such short half-lives there are no commercially significant compounds of francium.

column33: Latin: radius (ray).
column34: Silvery-white metal. Intensely radioactive.
column38: Found in uranium ores at 1 part per 3 million parts uranium.
column39: Used in treating cancer because of the gamma rays it gives off.

column33: Greek: akis, aktinos (ray).
column34: Heavy, silvery-white, very radioactive metal
column38: Extremely rare, found in all uranium ores. Usually obtained by treating radium with neutrons in a reactor.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named for Thor, Norse god of thunder.
column34: Heavy, gray, soft, malleable, ductile, radioactive metal.
column38: Found in various minerals like monazite and thorite.
column39: Used in making strong alloys. Also in ultraviolet photoelectric cells. It is a common ingredient in high-quality lenses. Bombarded with neutrons make uranium-233, a nuclear fuel.

column33: Greek: proto and actinium (parent of actinium); it forms actinium when it radioactively decays.
column34: Very rare, silvery-white, extremely radioactive metal.
column35: Fredrich Soddy, John Cranston, Otto Hahn, Lise Meitner
column38: Does not occur in nature. Found among fission products of uranium, thorium, and plutonium.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named for the planet Uranus.
column34: Silvery-white, dense, ductile, malleable, radioactive metal.
column38: Occurs in many rocks, but in large amounts only in such minerals as pitchblende and carnotite.
column39: For many centuries it was used as a pigment for glass. Now it is used as a fuel in nuclear reactors and in bombs.

column33: Named for the planet Neptune.
column34: Rare, silvery radioactive metal.
column38: Produced by bombarding uranium with slow neutrons.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named for the planet Pluto.
column34: Silvery-white, extremely radioactive artificially produced metal.
column38: Found rarely in some uranium ores. Made by bombarding uranium with neutrons.
column39: Used in bombs and reactors. Small quantities are used in thermo-electric generators.

column33: Named for the American continent, by analogy with europium.
column34: Silvery-white, artificially produced radioactive metal.
column38: Produced by bombarding plutonium with neutrons.
column39: Americium-241 is currently used in smoke detectors.

column33: Named in honor of Pierre and Marie Curie.
column34: Silvery, malleable, synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Made by bombarding plutonium with helium ions. So radioactive it glows in the dark.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named after Berkeley, California the city of its discovery.
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Some compounds have been made and studied. Made by bombarding americium with alpha particles.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named after the state and University of California.
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal. Powerful neutron emitter.
column38: Made by bombarding curium with helium ions.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of the scientist Albert Einstein.
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column35: Argonne, Los Alamos, U of Calif
column38: Made by bombarding uranium with neutrons.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of the scientist Enrico Fermi.
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column35: Argonne, Los Alamos, U of Calif
column38: Produced by bombarding lighter transuranium elements with still lighter particles or by neutron capture.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of the scientist Dmitri Ivanovitch Mendeleyev, who devised the periodic table.
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Made by bombarding einsteinium with helium ions.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of Alfred Nobel, who invented dynamite and founded Nobel prize.
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Made by bombarding curium with carbon-13
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of Ernest O. Lawrence, inventor of the cyclotron.
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Produced by bombarding californium with boron ions.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of Ernest Rutherford
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Made by bombarding californium-249 with beams of carbon-12 and 13, which produced an isotope with half lives of 4+ and 3 sec.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of Otto Hahn
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Made by bombarding californium-249 with a beam of nitrogen-15
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of Glenn Seaborg, American physical chemist known for research on transuranium elements.
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column35: Soviet Nuclear Research/ U. of Cal at Berkeley
column38: Made by bombarding californium-249 with oxygen-18.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of Niels Bohr
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Obtained by bombarding bismuth-204 with chromium-54.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of Henri Hess, Swiss born Russian chemist known for work in thermodydamics.
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Formed by the bombardment of lead-208 with iron-58.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Named in honor of Lise Mietner
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Obtained by bombarding bismuth-209 with iron-58.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Un (one) nun (one) nilium (zero)
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Made by bombarding bismuth-209 with cobolt-59.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.

column33: Un (one) nun (one) unium (one)
column34: Synthetic radioactive metal.
column38: Made by bombarding bismuth-209 with nickel-60.
column39: It has no significant commercial applications.
